items.title: Unnecessary mandatory dependencies
items.body:
Right now, I see imports from panda in:

https://github.com/blaze/odo/blob/e62822a6dcc87d48cfee0207c9ca84a464d702f3/odo/convert.py#L4
https://github.com/blaze/odo/blob/e62822a6dcc87d48cfee0207c9ca84a464d702f3/odo/into.py#L20

and imports to dask in:
https://github.com/blaze/odo/blob/e62822a6dcc87d48cfee0207c9ca84a464d702f3/odo/chunks.py#L8

To my understanding, those imports should only be in their corresponding backend file, so that these imports don't become mandatory installs. I understand, that pandas and dask are popular packages, though there should be no external dependencies without good reason, and for those mentioned lines, I don't see one.

The functions in `convert.py` can probably just simply moved to the backend file, while the list of `not_appendable_types` might need a mechanism to be appended from any backend.

items.title: Datashape not Record Type?
items.body:
I'm trying to use Odo because I would like to load a few csv's into a sqlite3 database - one of which is over 30gb in size. However, when I try to load the csv's the datashape is not recognized as a record type:

    AssertionError: datashape must be Record type, got 0 * {msno: string, is_churn: int64}

I attempted to use discover and resource (as seen in the docs), but this didn't work and it was unsure of types (ie: "?string"). So I then tried to hardcode like so:

    odo(f, db, dshape='var * {msno: string, is_churn: int64}')

but still, this didn't fix the assertion error for isrecord().

I also looked at stack overflow, but neither of  the two related questions had been answered [1][2].

Apologies if this isn't the place for this, but I'm unsure of where to turn for an answer after consulting the docs and stackoverflow/google.

[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44598799/python-odo-sql-assertionerror-datashape-must-be-record-type-got-0
[2]https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46287776/using-odo-to-load-csv-postgres-on-aws

items.title: Bulk Loaders and Exports
items.body:
Hi,

I've used odo in some of my smaller projects and enjoy it, but with others the current data migrations I do use pyodbc and calls to utilities like [bcp](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/tools/bcp-utility) and [nzload](https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSULQD_7.1.0/com.ibm.nz.load.doc/c_load_nzload_command.html) due to the size of the data I am importing/exporting.

I don't see much documentation around utilities like these in Odo, but I did see that [pg_bulkload](http://odo.pydata.org/en/latest/perf.html) was not implemented yet.

I was wondering if there was any movement in this space and if there is on boarding documentation for somebody that might like to assist or work on some contributions relating to these bulk import/export utilities? If that doesn't fit the project any ideas or suggestions for somebody interested in creating an extension library for Odo with these utilities?

Thanks.

items.title: Support Nullable Foreign-Keys
items.body:
A database I'm trying to connect to has a nullable foreign-key which odo doesn't currently handle:

**Test Case:**
```python
import blaze as bz
from numpy.random import randint
import sqlalchemy as sa


engine = sa.create_engine('sqlite://')
metadata = sa.MetaData(bind=engine)

T1 = sa.Table(
    'NullableForeignKeyDemo',
    metadata,
    sa.Column('pkid', sa.Integer, primary_key=True),
    sa.Column('label_id', sa.Integer, sa.ForeignKey("ForeignKeyLabels.pkid"), nullable=True),
)

T2 = sa.Table(
    'ForeignKeyLabels',
    metadata,
    sa.Column('pkid', sa.Integer, primary_key=True),
    sa.Column('label', sa.String),
)

metadata.create_all()

records1 = [
    {'pkid': idx, 'label_id': int(value)}
    for idx, value
    in enumerate(randint(0, 10, 10))
]
records1[-1]['label_id'] = None  # foreign-key is nullable!

records2 = [
    {'pkid': pkid, 'label': chr(pkid+65)}
    for pkid in range(10)
]
with engine.connect() as conn:
    conn.execute(T1.insert(), records1)
    conn.execute(T2.insert(), records2)

data = bz.data(T1)
```
As can be seen the inferred datashape doesn't recognize the map key as being nullable:
```python
In [42]: data
Out[42]: <'Table' data; _name='_4', dshape='var * {  pkid: int32,  label_id: map[int32, {pkid:...'>
```

items.title: Regression: mapped (foreign-key) columns not numpy compatible!
items.body:
Attn: @llllllllll - commit 689894ccb0bca5687ef0bd9ca39ecf0c80cd747b introduced a regression whereby no foreign-key columns can pass through odo.

**Repro:**
```python
# setup and populate a db with a foreign-key
from itertools import chain

import blaze as bz
import numpy as np
from numpy.random import choice, randint
from odo import odo
import pandas as pd
import sqlalchemy as sa

engine = sa.create_engine('sqlite://')
metadata = sa.MetaData(bind=engine)
T1 = sa.Table(
    'demo',
    metadata,
    sa.Column('timestamp', sa.String, primary_key=True),
    sa.Column('label_id', sa.SmallInteger, sa.ForeignKey("labels.pkid"), nullable=False),
)
T2 = sa.Table(
    'labels',
    metadata,
    sa.Column('pkid', sa.SmallInteger, primary_key=True),
    sa.Column('label', sa.String(1), nullable=False),
)

metadata.create_all()


labels = pd.DataFrame(
    list(zip(range(4), ['A','B','C','D'])),
    columns=['pkid', 'label']
)
odo(labels, T2)
```
Attempting to pull out the data gives a not numpy-compatible error:

items.title: S3(CSV) to CSV routes through DataFrames unnecessarily
items.body:
I’m testing out odo’s s3 functionality with a round trip of local CSV -> S3 CSV -> local CSV. The first leg of this round trip seems to work fine, but on the return trip, it’s not simply getting the file as I would expect. Instead, the CSV ends up with numeric fields clearly manipulated (e.g. 39.00 is changed to 39.0).

Looking into what’s happening here, it looks like the S3(CSV) to CSV path is happening through a conversion to a Temp(CSV) first (hitting [`s3_text_to_text`](https://github.com/blaze/odo/blob/0.5.0/odo/backends/aws.py#L213)), which then results in hitting [`append_object_to_csv`](https://github.com/blaze/odo/blob/0.5.0/odo/backends/csv.py#L201), which will convert the CSV into and out of a DataFrame, because there is no explicit Temp(CSV) to CSV call defined.

I’m a bit confused as to why this doesn’t just call the S3 object’s `get_contents_to_filename` method, as [`s3_text_to_temp_text`](https://github.com/blaze/odo/blob/0.5.0/odo/backends/aws.py#L203) does. Perhaps it was assumed that there would be a Temp(x) -> x path defined everywhere and the move from S3 to temp would just take care of everything. Since there’s not, I think we should just get the file directly to the output path given.

Since this is blocking me right now, I’ll work on a fix and submit a PR if/when I get it working. Just wanted to put this issue out there for any discussion on the expected behavior.

items.title: Passing `s3` kwarg to odo gives TypeError
Support for redshift UNLOAD to S3
items.body:
Parking this here, as it doesn't look like it's supported. 

Redshift will unload potentially multiple CSVs to an s3 [prefix](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/latest/dg/r_UNLOAD.html). This is supported by the [redshift dialect](http://sqlalchemy-redshift.readthedocs.io/en/latest/commands.html#sqlalchemy_redshift.commands.UnloadFromSelect) just like the CopyCommand that's used.

Happy to look into this, if you have any pointers.

I also asked [here](https://github.com/blaze/odo/issues/34#issuecomment-215593436) to connect the conversations.

Hello, 

Take this example:

```
import odo
import pandas as pd
odo.odo('mssql+pyodbc://MyMSSQLServer::MyTable',
        'hdfstore://c:/workspace/MyHDFFile.h5::/MyTable', schema='dbo')

type(h.select('/data', 'index <= 1').MyField.name)
```

I'm happy to try to code this, but if someone could point at the right files/lines of code to try, I'd appreciate it. I'm not familiar with how this program works.

Thanks.

items.title: Mongo support on Windows
items.body:
All indications are that MongoDB support on Windows has been broken and not used for some time.  If this is mistaken, we would love to hear about your usecase.

Due to support overhead and the incurred development inertia, my preference for dealing with mongo on windows given current development resources is the following:
- Disable mongo on windows, skipping the test suite, etc.
- Document the lack of support on windows appropriately
- Solicit end users who need mongo on windows to make their usecase known.

I propose disabling mongo support on windows for the full 0.4.1 release in odo and the next bugfix release of blaze.

@sandhujasmine I believe you have some familiarity with mongo and blaze: what's your experience here, specifically w.r.t. windows?

items.title: odo 0.4.0 should require toolz 0.7.3
items.body:
Importing odo 0.4.0 just now gave an error traced back to:

``` text
File ".../python2.7/site-packages/odo-0.4.0-py2.7.egg/odo/chunks.py", line 5, in <module>
    from toolz import memoize, first, peek
ImportError: cannot import name peek
```

It appears that `peek` was introduced to toolz in v0.7.3, but odo's requirements still specify >= 0.7.2 for toolz. Bumping the required version to >= 0.7.3 should fix this problem.

items.title: Pathological runtimes with specific CSV files
items.body:
As reported by @jbednar 

The file `data.csv` has 3 named columns with trailing commas and a trailing space.  `pandas.read_csv()` can handle this fine, while `odo` completes, but takes several hundred times longer to complete.

```
$ head data.csv
a,b,c, 
-1.3700737E7, 6275190.0, w, 
-1.3700711E7, 6275195.0, w, 
-1.3702081E7, 6274898.5, w, 
-1.3701948E7, 6274931.0, w, 
-1.3701793E7, 6275088.5, w, 
-1.3701224E7, 6274994.5, w, 
-1.370176E7, 6274780.0, w, 
-1.370215E7, 6274539.5, w, 
-1.3702123E7, 6274279.0, w, 

$ wc -l data.csv
  306675005 data.csv
```

`odo`ing the first 10**6 lines of this file into a `DataFrame` takes approximately 30s, meaning the entire 300M line file will take upwards of 2.5 hours to load.

``` python
In [4]: %time odo('data_1E6.csv', DataFrame)
CPU times: user 29.7 s, sys: 74.6 ms, total: 29.8 s
Wall time: 29.8 s
Out[4]:
        a            b             c Unnamed: 3
0        -13700737    6275190.0    w 2015-10-23
1        -13700711    6275195.0    w 2015-10-23
2        -13702081    6274898.5    w 2015-10-23
3        -13701948    6274931.0    w 2015-10-23
4        -13701793    6275088.5    w 2015-10-23
5        -13701224    6274994.5    w 2015-10-23
6        -13701760    6274780.0    w 2015-10-23
7        -13702150    6274539.5    w 2015-10-23
8        -13702123    6274279.0    w 2015-10-23
9        -13702072    6274537.0    w 2015-10-23
10       -13701917    6274562.5    w 2015-10-23
```

The equivalent `pandas.read_csv()` call takes approximately 3 minutes to load _the entire file_.

The `odo` call has trouble with the trailing commas and trailing spaces.  It extracts an unnamed column, and the key performance killer is that odo [_converts the space in that column into a datetime_](https://github.com/blaze/odo/blob/master/odo/backends/pandas.py#L60-L61).

Fix is forthcoming.

items.title: csv header sniffer fails for utf-8 encoding
items.body:
Because the method to infer the header in the file takes exactly x bytes it can fail if the last byte is part of a multi-byte utf-8 character. The decoding of the first x bytes should ignore the errors see the [codecs](https://docs.python.org/3.4/library/codecs.html#error-handlers) documentation.

A possible solution is to replace invalid bytes with the unicode replacement character:

``` diff
--- a/odo/backends/csv.py
+++ b/odo/backends/csv.py
@@ -93,7 +93,7 @@ def infer_header(path, nbytes=10000, encoding='utf-8', **kwargs):
     if not raw:
         return True
     sniffer = PipeSniffer()
-    decoded = raw if PY2 else raw.decode(encoding)
+    decoded = raw if PY2 else raw.decode(encoding, 'replace')
     try:
         return sniffer.has_header(decoded)
     except csv.Error:

```

items.title: Option[String] exception converting to numpy types
items.body:
I'm running into a NotNumpyCompatible exception in trying to convert a CSV to a Pandas DataFrame that I don't think is quite right. The CSV was converted from a Teradata table which assigned it the following DataShape:

```
var * {  
  ACCT_ID: ?int64,  
  SVC_OWNR_CD: ?string[6, 'A'],  
  SVC_OWNR_LOB_CD: ?string[4, 'A'],  
  RWRDS_ENRLMT_IND: ?string[1, 'A'],  
  ANUL_FEE_AMT: ?float64,  
  BRNDD_PROD_ID: ?int64,  
  BRNDD_PROD_ID_PROD_NM: ?string['A'],  
  PROD_NM: ?string['A'],  
  PROD_DT: ?date,  
  EDW_PUBLN_ID: ?int64,  
  floattest: ?float64  
  }
```

I'm working on extending odo to Teradata, so the DataShape reflects conversions from nullable CHAR and VARCHAR SQL types, among others.

A partial traceback is below, but it seems to me that the unit_to_dtype function in numpy_dtype isn't properly identifying strings inside of Option instances. Specifically, the [line](https://github.com/ContinuumIO/odo/blob/master/odo/numpy_dtype.py#L27) `if isinstance(ds, Option) and ds.ty in (date_, datetime_, string):`, which should pull the ty attribute out and essentially "de-Option-ize" the type, doesn't seem to trigger. Unless I'm mistaken about the purpose of this logic, it seems designed to pull the string out of the option for numpy.

The following bastardized version of the unit_to_dtype logic shows how looking for instances of the String class find the string types inside options, but the current logic using an in expression does not.
#### Existing logic

```
def fake_unit_to_dtype(ds):
    if isinstance(ds, datashape.Option) and ds.ty in (datashape.date_, datashape.datetime_, datashape.string):
        print 'Swapping out ds {0} for ds.ty {1}'.format(ds, ds.ty)
    else:
        print 'Not happening for ds {}.'.format(ds)
for name, typ in dshape.measure.dict.items():
    if not 'date' in str(typ):
        #print odo.numpy_dtype.unit_to_dtype(typ)
        fake_unit_to_dtype(typ)
```

```
Not happening for ds ?int64.
Not happening for ds ?int64.
Not happening for ds ?string['A'].
Not happening for ds ?string[6, 'A'].
Not happening for ds ?string[4, 'A'].
Not happening for ds ?string[1, 'A'].
Not happening for ds ?float64.
Not happening for ds ?int64.
Not happening for ds ?string['A'].
Not happening for ds ?float64.
```

---
#### Modified logic

```
def fake_unit_to_dtype(ds):
    if isinstance(ds, datashape.Option) and isinstance(ds.ty, datashape.String):
        print 'Swapping out ds {0} for ds.ty {1}'.format(ds, ds.ty)
    else:
        print 'Not happening for ds {}.'.format(ds)
for name, typ in dshape.measure.dict.items():
    if not 'date' in str(typ):
        #print odo.numpy_dtype.unit_to_dtype(typ)
        fake_unit_to_dtype(typ)
```

```
Not happening for ds ?int64.
Not happening for ds ?int64.
Swapping out ds ?string['A'] for ds.ty string['A']
Swapping out ds ?string[6, 'A'] for ds.ty string[6, 'A']
Swapping out ds ?string[4, 'A'] for ds.ty string[4, 'A']
Swapping out ds ?string[1, 'A'] for ds.ty string[1, 'A']
Not happening for ds ?float64.
Not happening for ds ?int64.
Swapping out ds ?string['A'] for ds.ty string['A']
Not happening for ds ?float64.
```

**Is this expected behavior or a bug?**

(more traceback details below as promised)

``` ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
NotNumpyCompatible                        Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-24-ea1538c00b12> in <module>()
----> 1 dtypes, parse_dates = odo.numpy_dtype.dshape_to_pandas(dshape)

I am trying to use odo to convert a JSON log to CSV, the problem is, that half of my JSON-lines miss the "source_allocated"-key-value-pair, so the discovery works fine:

odo.discover(odo.resource('jsonlines://events.json'))

  feed: string,
  feed_url: string,

I suspect a deadlock because the issue disappears iff I remove the `ssh.connect` in https://github.com/ContinuumIO/odo/blob/master/odo/backends/tests/test_ssh.py#L24, and strace shows a litany of:

```
[pid 10354] futex(0x180ef0a0, FUTEX_WAIT_PRIVATE, 0, NULL <unfinished ...>
[pid 10381] futex(0x180ef0a0, FUTEX_WAKE_PRIVATE, 1 <unfinished ...>
[pid 10354] <... futex resumed> )       = -1 EAGAIN (Resource temporarily unavailable)
[pid 10381] <... futex resumed> )       = 0
[pid 10354] select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 8000} <unfinished ...>
[pid 10381] select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 100000} <unfinished ...>
[pid 10354] <... select resumed> )      = 0 (Timeout)
[pid 10354] select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 16000}) = 0 (Timeout)
[pid 10354] select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 32000}) = 0 (Timeout)
[pid 10354] select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 34890}
```

You may not want to do network IO in imports, as this may cause some thread creation (https://docs.python.org/2/library/threading.html#importing-in-threaded-code). I would suggest to instead implement the skip functionality using memoization.

In [3]: !cat tst.csv
a,1
b,2

raises

``` python
...
/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.4.3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/gzip.py in write(self, data)
    341         if len(data) > 0:
    342             self.size = self.size + len(data)
--> 343             self.crc = zlib.crc32(data, self.crc) & 0xffffffff
    344             self.fileobj.write( self.compress.compress(data) )
    345             self.offset += len(data)

I believe that

``` python
ipdb> zlib.crc32(data.encode('utf-8'), self.crc) & 0xffffffff

items.title: `NotImplementedError` vs `NotImplemented`
items.body:
Maybe I'm missing something, but why does Odo detect and reroute on `NotImplementedError` instead of `NotImplemented`?

Python docs [advise](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#NotImplementedError) raising `NotImplementError` from abstract methods that are supposed to be overwritten by derived classes.

[`NotImplemented`](https://docs.python.org/2/library/constants.html#NotImplemented) is intended for "rich comparisons" and choosing which object should handle these comparisons.

Odo's path choosing seems to be more analogous to the latter rather than the former. So maybe backends should return `NotImplemented` instead of raising `NotImplementedError`. This might benefit performance slightly too, since raising and catching exceptions probably incurs more overhead than returning and checking constants.

items.body:
@mrocklin, I was trying to get a new version for python 2.7 in binstar, as instructed by doing:

```
conda install -c blaze into -f
```

and I was still getting my previous error:

```
    /Users/cdoig/anaconda/envs/topik/lib/python2.7/site-packages/into/convert.pyc in series_to_array(s, dshape, **kwargs)
         66 @convert.register(np.ndarray, pd.Series, cost=0.1)
         67 def series_to_array(s, dshape=None, **kwargs):
    ---> 68     dtype = datashape.to_numpy_dtype(datashape.dshape(dshape))
         69     sdtype = s.dtype
         70     values = s.values
```

I then checked binstar and wasn't able to find a new package for 2.7. I was just seeing this package info:

```
depends [u'datashape', u'multipledispatch', u'networkx', u'numpy 1.9*', u'pandas', u'python 3.4*', u'toolz']
```

I then discovered that binstar was creating the same name for all versions:

```
586[warning] Distribution osx-64/into-0.2.2-8_g68222bc.tar.bz2 already exists ... removing 
587Exit BINSTAR_BUILD_RESULT=success
```

and it was removing the previous built package (with different python and numpy versions):
e.g.:
https://binstar.org/blaze/into/builds/85/9#log
https://binstar.org/blaze/into/builds/85/8#log

and that the one that remained was the latest:
https://binstar.org/blaze/into/builds/85/11, with numpy=1.9 and python=3.4

I've opened a PR #112 to add the python version to the string, like @tswicegood does in conda-env:
https://github.com/conda/conda-env/blob/develop/conda.recipe/meta.yaml

But still haven't figured out how to include the numpy version.

items.title: Importing '*.csv' into DataFrame errors with: File *.csv does not exist
items.body:
A common use of `into` would be to import/convert all of the csv files in a directory. This works fine if there is a prefix to the asterix, e.g.,
`into(pd.DataFrame, 'examp*.csv')`

but errors if there is no prefix,

```
>>> into(pd.DataFrame, '*.csv')
...
IOError: File *.csv does not exist
```

items.title: Importing multiple csv's into DataFrame fails with null values
items.body:
In 0.2.1, importing multiple csv's, at least one of which has null values, results in errors.
### One csv has null vaules in a column and another doesn't

Error:
`Exception: Integer column has NA values`

Example:

examp1.csv:

```
a,b,c
1,2,3
4,5,6
7,8,9
```

examp2.csv:

```
a,b,c
1,2,3
4,,6
7,8,9
```

examp.py

```
into(pd.DataFrame, 'examp*.csv')
```
### Multiple csv's have null values in the same column

Error:
`ValueError: cannot convert float NaN to integer`

Example:

examp1.csv:

```
a,b,c
1,2,3
4,,6
7,8,9
```

examp2.csv:

```
a,b,c
1,,2
3,4,5
6,7,8
```

examp.py

```
into(pd.DataFrame, 'examp*.csv')
```

In both of these cases importing the csv's one at a time works fine.

items.title: Bring into docs under pydata domain
items.body:
They're currently hosted at http://into.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ but we can change the domain.

This should be possible with some `CNAME` magic in the right place.

items.title: SparkSQL should use PyHive SQL generation if available
items.body: SparkSQL officially speaks Hive.  I think we're currently sending it MySQL and possibly through the wrong method.  If we have pyhive install we should probably use that instead.

items.title: Migrate Spark recipes from blaze
items.body: Blaze still holds our recipes for PySpark and SparkSQL in the old "just into" style.  These should be brought over to into and translated into `append`/`convert` style.

items.title: HDFStore -> SQL not supported
items.body:
There doesn't seem to be a way to get from an HDFStore to SQL, though you can go from an HDFStore to a Dataframe and a DataFrame to SQL.

This fails:

``` python
blz.into('sqlite:///bayarea.db::buildings', 'hdfstore://bayarea.h5::/buildings')
```

with this error:

``` pytb
NetworkXNoPath: node <class 'pandas.io.pytables.FrameFixed'> not reachable from <class '_abcoll.Iterator'>
```

But this works fine:

``` python
blz.into(pd.DataFrame, 'hdfstore://bayarea.h5::/buildings')
```

And this works fine:

``` python
buildings = store['buildings']
blz.into('sqlite:///bayarea.db::buildings', buildings)
```

items.title: Append sqlalchemy.Select to sqlalchemy.Table
items.body: Sometimes we might want to do a computation and then keep the result in the database as another table.  To do this Blaze needs an `append(sqlalchemy.Table, sqlalchemy.Select)` implementation.  Presumably there is some way to generate an approprate `INSERT INTO ...` statement through sqlalchemy.

items.title: HDFS(CSV) -> Hive/Impala
items.body:
It would be nice to automate the metadata loading process from CSV files on HDFS into the Hive metastore.  In principle the `CREATE TABLE` statement can be handled as we already do in `backends/sql_csv.py`.  Some novel parts
1.  A new HDFS metaclass (similar to `Chunks`)
2.  Need to download a csv file from HDFS to the local machine so that we can discover its datashape
3.  Ideally we only pull a few hundred kilobyte sample, not the whole thing.

The metaclass can probably be a no-op.

PyWebHDFS or more generally the WebHDFS web interface seems like a reasonable approach to interacting with a foreign HDFS.  I'm running into issues with it now though; it seems that some link gets internally redirected and becomes opaque.  

We may want to handle the downloading/HTTP request ourselves so that we can use an HTTP RANGE GET request (or anything really that lets us download just some of a file.)

cc @quasiben

This is sort of a gateway issue to handling HDFS data generally.  `HDFS(CSV) -> pyspark.RDD` could be a thing as well as (if we find a suitable library, `HDFS(CSV) -> HDFS(Parquet)`.
